content.rendered:
Peculiar sans serifs are the common thread this week on Friday Likes with work from London, Helsinki, and Montreal.

8th Berlin Biennale by Zak Group

This year marked the eighth edition of the Berlin Biennale which was cleverly presented by London-based Zak Group through a split “8” that served as brackets for the bulk of the printed, digital, and outdoor communications. Featuring commissioned aphorisms from artist Agatha Gothe-Snape, the identity is very verbose but the shift in filled-in type and stroked-type provides enough change to keep it lively, along with a simple color palette. The winning concept here was cutting that 8 in half, which also looks like two “B”s back to back (for Berlin Biennale), and the bespoke condensed typeface by Radim Pesko. See full project

Fazer Café by Kokoro & Moi

A staple of Helsinki since 1891, Fazer Café has opened various locations in recent years with an identity by local firm Kokoro & Moi that features a couple of custom fonts — a sans and a chisel — based on the signage of the original location. Set in blue, yellow, and gold, the letterforms occupy everything from coffee cups to shopping bags to walls. It’s simple, elegant, and bold and you can spell CAFÉ with cups, so that’s awesome. See full project here.

BNT Studio by Emanuel Cohen

At first, I wasn’t convinced by the logo for BNT Studio, a design-y product distributor in Canada, designed by Montreal, Quebec-based Emanuel Cohen but the more I saw it repeated in the identity, taking up large swaths of space yet feeling light and airy, the more I liked it. It’s a simple and attractive monogram that despite being asymmetrical with a circle on the left of the “N” and a tiny horizontal line on the right feels perfectly in balance. The black, warm grays, and salmon color palette is super nice as well. See full project.
